title: Standard Form of Hyperbola with Center (h,k)
text:
The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center (h,k) and transverse axis parallel to the x-axis is
$$ rac{\left(x-hight)^2}{a^2}- rac{\left(y-kight)^2}{b^2}=1$$
where
the length of the transverse axis is 2a
the coordinates of the vertices are (h+a,k),(h-a,k)
the length of the conjugate axis is $$2b$$
the coordinates of the co-vertices are (h,k+b),(h,k-b)
the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$
the coordinates of the foci are (h+c,k),(h-c,k)
The asymptotes of the hyperbola coincide with the diagonals of the central rectangle. The length of the rectangle is 2a and its width is $$2b$$. The slopes of the diagonals are $$ rac{b}{a}$$ and $$ rac{-b}{a}$$, and each diagonal passes through the center (h,k). Using the point-slope formula, it is simple to show that the equations of the asymptotes are $$y= rac{b}{a} \left(x-hight)+k$$ and $$y= rac{-b}{a} \left(x-hight)+k$$.
(See the left image)

The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center (h,k) and transverse axis parallel to the y-axis is
$$ rac{\left(y-kight)^2}{a^2}- rac{\left(x-hight)^2}{b^2}=1$$
where
the length of the transverse axis is 2a
the coordinates of the vertices are (h,k+a),(h,k-a)
the length of the conjugate axis is $$2b$$
the coordinates of the co-vertices are (h+b,k),(h-b,k)
the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$
the coordinates of the foci are (h,k+c),(h,k-c)
Using the reasoning above, the equations of the asymptotes are $$y= rac{a}{b} \left(x-hight)+k$$ and $$y= rac{-a}{b} \left(x-hight)+k$$.

title: Transverse Axis
text: Which axis is transverse axis on? We can tell based on the coordinates of the vertices and foci.

title: Appropriate Standard Form
text: Since the transverse axis is on the x-axis, which standard form for hyperbola should we use?

title: Center
text: We start by identifying the center. The center is halfway between the vertices $$(0,-2)$$ and $$(6,-2)$$. We can apply the midpoint formula $$(h,k)=(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2},\frac{y_1+y_2}{2})$$. What is the center (h,k)?

title: Vertices
text: It is given that vertices are $$(0,-2)$$ and $$(6,-2)$$. The length of the transverse axis, 2a, is bounded by the vertices. We can thus find a by dividing the length between the two vertices by $$2$$. What is a in the standard form of hyperbola?

title: Foci
text: It is given that foci are $$(-2,-2)$$ and $$(8,-2)$$. The coordinates of foci are also given by $$(h+c,k)$$ and $$(h-c,k)$$ where c is the distance of the foci from the center. We can use $$(h+c,k)=(8,-2)$$ with $$h=3$$ that we found earlier to find c. What is c associated with the hyperbola?

title: Finding $$b$$
text: We know that $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$, we can thus rearrange the equation to $$b=\sqrt{c^2-a^2}$$. With the a and c previously found, what is $$b$$?

title: Equation
text: Having found $$h$$, k, a and $$b$$, we can now substitute them into the standard form equation $$\frac{\left(x-h\right)^2}{a^2}-\frac{\left(y-k\right)^2}{b^2}=1$$
